topics.body:
"@twistedmetalero":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/542f833563687241d1940100#post_542f833563687241d1940100

topics.author: 505696b47f123b37e800effa

topics.body:
"@uc9":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/542f95e363687209af100000#post_542f95e363687209af100000
I just wonder what will happen to Tibet and Xinjiang province if the regime does fall. Maybe it'll end up like the Soviet Union?
A part of me believes that Tibet and Xinjiang would be better off under the administration of a democratic China rather than full independence. Hopefully under rules that respect their religions, peoples, and societies while having access to the economic and social benefits of Chinese citizens. And not be treated as second rate. I do not want them to separate.
topics.author: 4fde5cee945b700a970060fc

topics.body:
"@uc9":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/542f93df63687238df670000#post_542f93df63687238df670000
The cynical part of me thinks the protestors want more than democracy, else why protest in HK which is the business capital and one of the more autonomous places in China
topics.author: 4fe16df67f123b13e400003f

topics.body:
"@uc9":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/542f978b6368725536950000#post_542f978b6368725536950000
Yes, it may be. But I'm more concerned about the social, political, secular, and economical consequences that may follow.
As much as I want a free China. I still want want them to remain a strong nation.
topics.author: 4fde5cee945b700a970060fc

topics.body:
"@SeraphimDawn":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/542f97e563687237a69c0100#post_542f97e563687237a69c0100
What I fear is if China ever decides to attack the Philippines, this might get America an excuse to annex us. We would be like Canada in Fallout 3.

topics.body:
"@Albus Fahrenheits":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/542f988a6368722d31240000#post_542f988a6368722d31240000
Apologies, but I'm not cynical enough to believe that my home country would try something like that, nor that the rest of the world would sit idly by and allow us to do so on the off-chance that we did try.

topics.body:
"@SeraphimDawn":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/542f9b9863687232cae80000#post_542f9b9863687232cae80000
Even now I see people rallying in the streets shouting "US troops out now". I'd fight alongside any American soldier but make no mistake, if they ever try to take our sovereignty, I'll gladly point rifles at them.

topics.body:
"@Albus Fahrenheits":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/542f9cf56368722c71050000#post_542f9cf56368722c71050000
Here's something that will cream your pants; isolationist ideals in the usa have reached a 50 year all time high:
(washingtonpost article hyperlinked in image)
"!http://img.washingtonpost.com/blogs/worldviews/files/2013/12/12-3-2013-20.png!":http://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/worldviews/wp/2013/12/04/american-isolationism-just-hit-a-50-year-high-why-that-matters/

There's a reason why the usa isn't sending troops back into Iraq or invading Syria cause it would be straight up political suicide.
topics.author: 38b55cdf63616403d7560600

topics.body:
"@Albus Fahrenheits":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/542f9cf56368722c71050000#post_542f9cf56368722c71050000
That is the problem with having the US "aiding" other countries in the times of conflict. They don't seem to respect sovereignty. Their foreign policies are significantly what makes the world hate the US. As seen in Iraq and Japan(during the early postwar era). Strangely enough, the Japanese actually liked it when the country was under General MacArthur's administration.

Some South Koreans also believe that the US forces who are stationed in their country are what is causing the North Koreans to lose their shit. Some want them OUT.
topics.author: 4fde5cee945b700a970060fc

topics.body:
"@uc9":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/542f9de76368723cc5200000#post_542f9de76368723cc5200000
I'm glad to see that. To be perfectly honest, this whole "world police" really needs to come to an end. The Cold War is over, and the only thing this gunboat diplomacy is doing now is embarrassing our allies and pissing off otherwise neutral people.

topics.body:
"@uc9":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/542fa03c6368726214480100#post_542fa03c6368726214480100
I'm Canadian, just born in Taiwan. I dunno, but a transition certainly won't be peaceful. That's my guess. Chinese have been subjected to autocratic one-government rule since the first Imperial Dynasty for most of their history, many may have to be painstakingly re-educated on democratic systems. They might end up like Russia...
